Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: Before starting a large-scale project tomorrow, the carpenter needs to read and interpret blueprints, drawings, and technical documents
Story: I stared at the invitation on the kitchen table, my sister’s handwriting looping across the card: “Family dinner, 7 PM. Don’t be late!” I could almost hear her voice, teasing but firm, reminding me how much it meant to everyone that I show up. Being the eldest, I was supposed to set the example, to be present, to laugh and share stories over Mom’s roast chicken. But my mind kept drifting to the thick stack of blueprints spread across my workbench in the garage. Tomorrow, I’d be leading my first big carpentry project—an entire custom kitchen. I needed tonight to pore over every measurement, every technical note, to make sure I didn’t miss a single detail. My boss was counting on me, and so was the client. The weight of both worlds pressed on my chest. I wanted to be the dependable sister, but I also needed to be the prepared carpenter. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Dinner at 7.” I glanced at the clock, heart pounding, torn between the warmth of my family and the silent call of my unfinished plans.
